oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cumberland Gap: historic site marker
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Roughly bounded by Colwyn, Cumberland, Pennlyn, and the L & N Railroad tracks, Cumberland Gap, Claiborne Co., TN

Black and white photograph of Cumberland Gap historic marker; white church visible in background; sign reads "Cumberland Gap: First explored 1750; Long Hunters used it until 1760, and Daniel Boone in 1769, cutting the Wilderness Trail through it in 1775. Hosts of pioneers followed even before the road was built in 1796. Postal service was established in 1795 and a post office in 1803. The Gap changed hands 4 times during War Between the States."

For over two hundred years, Cumberland Gap has served as a significant passageway to the lands west of the Appalachian mountains. The Cumberland Gap Historic District is significant as evidence to the patterns of Claiborne County's history as a late nineteenth and early twentieth century mining town funded by foreign capitalists as well as its associations with Wilderness Road. American Association, Limited had its headquarters in Cumberland Gap.

Cumberland Gap: First explored 1750; Long Hunters used it until 1760, and Daniel Boone in 1769, cutting the Wilderness Trail through it in 1775. Hosts of pioneers followed even before the road was built in 1796. Postal service was established in 1795 and a post office in 1803. The Gap changed hands 4 times during Was Between the States.
